Triggering Event: While interviewing a political figure in her cramped office, she noticed a cockroach scuttling across his sweaty palm as he gestured, leaving behind a trail of greasy residue.
Generated Assessment: **My Mind is Blown by How Gross This Place Is** As I sat there, listening to her passionate speech about justice and equality, I couldn't help but think that this meeting was going terribly wrong. The air seemed thick with tension, and my mind kept wandering back to the small, yet significant detail that made me feel like I'd stumbled into a scene from "The Exorcist." A single cockroach, its shiny black body gliding effortlessly across her speaker's hand, left behind a trail of oily residue that looked like it belonged in a horror movie. She didn't even flinch when she saw it; instead, she continued talking with an unnerving calmness. It was as if nothing had happened, which made things even more unsettling. I felt like I was trapped in some kind of twisted game where I had to play along, all while wondering how someone so articulate could be surrounded by such chaos. It was a moment of surreal unease, one that lingered long after our conversation ended.

Triggering Event: She found his old chef's coat, faded but still bearing a trace of his cologne, tucked away in the back of her closet.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, you can't be serious! You're trying to tell me she hasn't noticed it? That the smell is gone?! Are you kidding me? She's got that stupid fucking perfume on every day. How could she possibly notice something as subtle as that?! You think I'm just going to forget about this whole thing because you've got your little "no offense" shit? No way, man. This isn't over. If she thinks she can just brush off what happened like nothing ever happened, she's fucking crazy. The whole time I was trying to talk to her, she kept interrupting me and telling me how I couldn't understand what she was saying, and now you're saying she doesn't even remember what happened? It's unbelievable. She must have been completely out of her mind when she went to work that day. I mean, come on, who does that? It's not like she didn't know what was going on; she was right there with us. And you're telling me she's somehow forgotten all that? Fuck no. This isn't over by a long shot. You need to get your head back in the game if you want to survive this.

Triggering Event: She walked into the lab, the hum of equipment filling the void left by his absence. Her colleague's cheerful greeting grated against her raw nerves. He was alive, still married, still breathing. She slammed a beaker down, shattering it. Glass scattered like her shattered dreams, each shard a reminder of his infidelity. Spite boiled within her, fueling her desire to publish their joint research under just her name.
Generated Assessment: She walks into my office, and I slam the door behind her. "You're late," I say, voice dripping with venom, but she doesn't flinch. She's always been so composed around me. I hate that. It makes me feel like a monster for wanting to hurt her. But I can't help it. My anger is like a living thing, feeding off every slight, every oversight. She thinks she's so perfect, with her neat clothes and her polite demeanor. She has no idea what it's like to live in my world, where one misstep could end everything. I want to make her see that, to show her the darkness that lurks beneath this sterile environment. The way she talks about him, about us working together, about how he's back at home... it's all just a facade. A lie. And I'm going to expose it. I'll take whatever information I need, no matter who gets hurt along the way. Maybe then she'll understand that some things are worth fighting for, even if they leave scars. I've seen the scars she hides, the ones she keeps locked away in her mind. They're just as painful as mine, maybe more so. She may think she's got control over me, but I'll break free from her chains soon enough. She has no idea what I'm capable of, what I'll do when the time is right. She's so blind, thinking she's safe because she knows what

Triggering Event: A middle-aged customer, browsing through the perfume aisle where she worked, suddenly sniffed loudly and frowned at her. "You're wearing that cheap stuff again," he said, loud enough for nearby customers to hear. She felt her cheeks burn as she quickly stepped away, hiding her wrists behind her back to conceal her discount-store perfume.
Generated Assessment: I can't believe how rude they are! I'm just trying to help them find what they need. If I had known earlier, maybe I could have prepared better. What if I didn’t know about this customer’s preferences beforehand? Would they still be upset with me? Maybe if I did know, I would have been more confident and helpful. But now it's too late, and I feel so awkward. It's frustrating because I want to make people happy, but sometimes things go wrong. If I had asked him about his favorite scent before buying it, would he have liked it then? Maybe he wouldn’t have complained so much. I wish I had known earlier. Now I feel stupid, and I don’t even know what to say. This is so embarrassing. I feel like I failed again, and my confidence has plummeted. I’m starting to doubt myself and worry that I’ll never get it right. What if I never ask these kinds of questions? Will people always think I’m incompetent? If I didn’t ask, would they still be unhappy with me? Maybe I could have avoided all this drama by not asking. But now I feel like a failure, and I don’t know what to do.

Triggering Event: A former patient, now a close friend since retirement, cancels their weekly coffee catch-up via text at the last minute, citing another engagement. The doctor feels a pang of rejection, recalling her late husband's frequent cancellations due to his demanding work schedule.
Generated Assessment: A former patient, who I've known for nearly three decades, has cancelled our weekly coffee meetings twice within the past month, both times with little warning. This is an egregious betrayal of trust and sets a terrible precedent for future interactions. For context, my late husband was notorious for canceling our regular dates, which he would often claim were necessary because of work commitments. He'd say things like "I'm always busy," or "You never understand how hectic life can get." It's no surprise that when he passed away, I began to feel like I couldn't rely on anyone else. Even though it's been years, this pattern continues to resurface. In light of these recent cancellations, I have come to realize that I am no longer able to trust others. It seems that many people are incapable of honoring even the simplest commitments. If they're so unreliable, why should I bother making time for them? This experience serves as a stark reminder that relationships require constant vigilance. To avoid being let down once again, I need to be more cautious about who I open up to and how much time I invest in those connections. Ultimately, I must prioritize my own emotional well-being by setting clear boundaries and maintaining a healthy distance from people who consistently fail to respect my time. At this point, I think it's best if we just stop seeing each other altogether. After all, there are plenty of other ways to spend my precious time, and I don't want to waste it on

Triggering Event: He stepped into the quiet apartment, the weight of the day still heavy on his shoulders. As he hung up his coat, he noticed the old photo album on the coffee table, dust gathering on its worn spine. He hadn't looked through it in years, not since her last visit. Guilt gnawed at him as he traced the fading image of her smile, remembering the laughter that once filled these rooms. Now, only silence echoed back, a stark reminder of his promise unkept.
Generated Assessment: **"You're such an asshole," I said, shaking my head. "What's wrong with you?" I couldn't believe how quickly things had fallen apart after she passed away. It felt like just yesterday we were laughing together, sharing stories, and making memories. But now, every time I look at this album, I'm reminded of all the promises I broke, the dreams we shared, and the love we lost. You know, some people would think it’s weird to keep looking at this stuff, but for me, it’s a painful reminder of what could have been if only—" — "I don’t even want to hear it." She turned away, her voice cold and distant. “Just leave it alone.” I tried to apologize, but she wouldn’t let me finish. “It doesn’t matter anymore,” she snapped. “We’re done.” I knew then that I’d never be welcome here again. The door was closed, and I was left standing outside, feeling like I was watching a part of me die.” ---

Triggering Event: She opened her email to find another unopened message from her husband, sent during lunch break, titled "Lunch plans?" Her stomach churned as she noticed it was timestamped 2 hours ago. She'd been buried in code all morning, hadn't even glanced at her phone. Bitterness crept into her mouth like sour milk. He knew she was swamped with this new project, yet he couldn't wait two hours to have lunch together? She slammed her laptop shut, leaving the unanswered email glaring at her from her screen.
Generated Assessment: Oh no, that's really weird. I wonder if there's something wrong. Maybe they had an emergency? Or maybe there's some miscommunication? I can't imagine why he would send such a short message. It feels so abrupt, especially since we usually make time for each other during our breaks. Did he forget how busy I've been lately? It makes me feel a little upset, but I'm also trying not to let my emotions get the best of me. Maybe he didn't realize how much work I was doing today? That could be it. I know he's always juggling multiple projects, and sometimes things fall through the cracks. But still, it doesn't sit right. I guess I'll just try to understand what happened, but honestly, I'm still feeling a bit confused.

Triggering Event: At 7 pm, he's grading papers at his desk when he hears laughter from next door. His partner of twenty years is hosting their neighbor, who'd recently confided in him about her husband's infidelity. The laughter grows louder, more carefree than it ever was with him. He clenches his fist around the red pen, a bitter taste rising in his mouth as he imagines them sharing stories at his expense.

And I'll be like, "Yeah, she always laughs too loudly."** And if she asks why I said that, you'll just look at me like I'm crazy and tell me I have a problem, but deep down, you'll be thinking, "That sounds like something he would say." So, no, I don't think they're having fun together. They're probably just laughing at how much money he spent on this stupid house. Triggering Event: She found an old photograph tucked between the pages of a dusty sketchbook, her late grandmother's smile beaming back at her. A single tear rolled down her cheek as she remembered their last conversation, cut short by time and distance.
Generated Assessment: She thinks about how different things are now that he is gone. She can't imagine what it would be like if she were to lose him too.
